Authors:
Rhudson Henrique Santos Ferreira Cruz, Kentaro Hosaka, Iuri
Goulart Baseia
Title:
Rediscovery of Cyathus badius, an ‘extinct’ species from the
Bonin Islands, Japan
Keywords:
Birds Nest Fungi, Endangered species, Japan, Phylogeny,
Taxonomy
Abstract:
The Japanese archipelago of Ogasawara presents a unique
and endemic fauna and flora, however a large portion of these species,
including members of the Kingdom Fungi, are now considered endangered or
extinct. During almost 80 years Cyathus badius was included in that
statistics and no recollection was occurred until a new expedition to
these islands in 2015. Comparisons with the holotype showed consistent
morphological features with the new specimen, and phylogenetic analysis
based on ribosomal ITS, LSU and concatenated dataset of ITS and LSU
placed C. badius in a highly supported clade with C. parvocinereus, C.
magnomuralis, C. lignilantanae and C. stercoreus. Because no DNA data
was obtained from the type species, is proposed here the epitification
of C. badius to designate this new sample as the DNA source for this
taxa.
